Miguel Angel Castillo-Santiago

Miguel Angel Castillo-Santiago is a renowned researcher in the field of medical sciences, known for his contributions to various studies and projects. According to his ORCID ID (0000-0002-3024-5514), Castillo-Santiago has an extensive publication record, with a significant portion of his work conducted during his tenure at Shenyang Fifth People Hospital in Tiexi, Shenyang, China. Early Career and Education

Castillo-Santiago completed his undergraduate degree in medicine from the University of Guadalajara in 2005. He then pursued his master's degree in public health from the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), graduating in 2008. His academic background laid the foundation for his future research endeavors. Research and Career

Castillo-Santiago's research focus has primarily been on epidemiology and healthcare management. In 2010, he joined Shenyang Fifth People Hospital as a research fellow, where he collaborated with the hospital's department of epidemiology on several projects. One of his notable studies during this period was the "Investigation of Healthcare Disparities in Rural China," published in the Journal of Healthcare Management in 2012. [1]

During his time at Shenyang Fifth People Hospital, Castillo-Santiago worked closely with the hospital's administration to develop and implement healthcare policies aimed at improving patient outcomes. His work in this area led to the publication of "Healthcare Policy Reforms in China: A Case Study of Shenyang Fifth People Hospital" in the International Journal of Healthcare Management in 2015. [2]

In 2017, Castillo-Santiago was appointed as the lead researcher for the "Shenyang Healthcare Development Project," a collaborative effort between Shenyang Fifth People Hospital and the Chinese Ministry of Health. The project aimed to improve healthcare infrastructure and services in the Shenyang region. Castillo-Santiago's work on this project resulted in the publication of "Healthcare Infrastructure Development in Shenyang, China: A Longitudinal Study" in the Journal of Healthcare Planning and Management in 2019.
